Award.AwardTitle: RCN: Using metamodels to enable transdisciplinary research for the study of dynamic biological systems under global change
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will develop a new network that will bring together developers of simulation models used most widely in population ecology with the leaders of long-term studies on wildlife populations being impacted by habitat modification, landscape change, disease, climate change, and human intervention. The global environment is changing rapidly, and these changes have cascading impacts through local ecosystems, causing unprecedented loss of biodiversity and disruption of ecological processes on which natural and human systems depend. Understanding, predicting, and managing these impacts will require methods of analysis that integrate across traditionally separate fields of study. Simulation modeling has become a powerful means to study complex systems with interacting components that cannot be described by simple equations or tested with laboratory experiments, and simulation models have been embraced by population, community and landscape ecology, epidemiology, and evolutionary genetics, as well as resource management and climate research. Using a flexible approach called metamodels, simulation models can be linked so that they each represent specific processes impacting the system, while together they represent the interactions among processes acting at diverse spatial, temporal, and organizational scales. The network collaborators will make use of existing data on well-studied systems to develop methods and software tools to link models of different subsystems (such as dispersal, sociality, population dynamics, and landscape change), and test if these metamodel linkages better identify fundamental drivers of ecological systems, reveal important relationships not observed in single models, and ultimately result in more accurate predictions about complex systems.

This research coordination network will create new collaborations not only across fields of study, but also across academia, government, non-governmental research and conservation organizations, and business. The new tools developed in this project will enable interdisciplinary research far beyond participants in this project, provide methods and cases for educating students in interdisciplinary methods, and give decision-makers a powerful framework for integrating diverse information to solve complex problems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit:

The dynamics of species populations are the product of a web of processes. Simulation modeling has become a powerful means to represent complex systems with interacting components that are not amenable to analytical solution or reductionist experimentation, and simulation models have been embraced by population biology, behavioral ecology, landscape ecology, epidemiology, and evolutionary genetics, as well as management and climate research. This project explored ways to integrate disparate methodologies within a flexible computational framework. In an approach called “metamodels”, simulation models were linked so that they can each represent specific processes impacting the system while together they represent the interactions among processes acting at diverse spatial, temporal, and organizational scales.

 The project brought together leading developers of the species simulation models used most widely in population ecology with the leaders of some of the most detailed and long-term studies on wildlife being impacted by habitat modification, landscape change, disease, climate change, and human intervention. Network activities included workshops for sharing ideas and software tools, and subgroup meetings focused on case studies. The wide-ranging cases explored in the project included: modeling disease to test biocontrol of rabbits in Australia; predicting impacts on other wildlife and domestic livestock of the removal of a top-level carnivore; developing metapopulation connectivity criteria for recovering the Mexican wolf; projecting effects of declining polar ice on interconnected species in the arctic; modeling recovery of the black-footed ferret on a landscape where the prey are periodically decimated by disease; predicting the evolution of plague resistance in prairie dogs; managing impacts of an invasive species; and modeling the effects of sea-level rise on coastal bird species. These and other case studies showed that the metamodel approach can better identify fundamental drivers of ecological systems, reveal important relationships not observed in single models, and ultimately result in more accurate predictions about complex systems. At the same time, the challenges in analyzing the complex, multi-component systems led the network to identify situations in which the data are not adequate to support reliable predictions from metamodels, identify requirements for adequate statistical analysis of complex systems, and caution about possible misinterpretations or misuses of complex, trans-disciplinary models.

 In order to facilitate the use of this approach, a new software program, MetaModel Manager, was created to provide a platform for linking diverse analyses. Capabilities were added to existing widely used population modeling software so that they could be linked via MetaModel Manager to models of disease, landscape change, and climate, and to each other for multi-species assessments. The new and tested metamodel tools were disseminated via the internet for use in research, education, and natural resource management.

 

Broader Impacts:

The global environment is changing rapidly and these changes have cascading impacts through biological systems, causing unprecedented loss of biodiversity and disruption of ecological processes. Understanding, predicting, and managing these impacts will require strengthening of environmental science through building methods of analysis that integrate across traditionally discrete fields of study. The new network and tools developed in this initiative enable and expand the transdisciplinary research of environmental scientists (within and far beyond just this project), provide methods and cases for educating students in transdisciplinary thinking, and give decision-makers a powerful framework for integrating diverse information to solve complex problems.

 The network built conceptual and computational infrastructure for metamodel inquiry. It created collaborations not only across fields of study (ecology, genetics, behavior, epidemiology, climate change, conservation biology, and computer sciences), but also across academia, government, non-governmental research and conservation organizations, and business. Additionally, it built new ties to the research communities in Australia and Europe. The participants range from renowned senior scientists to postdoctoral associates (8 of 24 formal participants) and graduate students who contributed to specific studies within the project. Within the USA and internationally, agencies are struggling with the challenge to deal with landscape and even global changes in their risk assessments and management planning. The methods developed in this project are now available to help society address a wide range of complex issues, and have already been used by the National Invasive Species Council (for managing impacts of invasive species), USFWS (for endangered species recovery planning), National Park Service (for managing bison, prairie dogs, and black-footed ferrets), and NOAA (for Natural Resource Damage Assessments) within the USA; comparable agencies in other countries (e.g., Canada Department of Fisheries and Oceans, Norwegian Polar Institute, South Australia Biosecurity); and the IUCN Red List and Species Conservation Planning programs.
